data.title: Professor Peter Higgs obituary: Theoretical physicist who won the Nobel prize
data.meta_description: His work on the mass of subatomic particles had a profound effect on our understanding of matter
data.text:
The way in which matter acquires mass, what we perceive as weight, was a problem that had long baffled scientists. They figured that the answer to this question would unlock many of the secrets of how the universe was formed. Peter Higgs, an unworldly and donnish academic, was reading some new research papers on July 16, 1964, when he had his eureka moment.

“I looked at one, realised what it meant, and then jumped up and shouted out loud, ‘Oh shit!’ ” he recalled in an interview in 2008. He spent the weekend walking through the hills outside Edinburgh like a latterday Wordsworth: “When I came back to work on Monday, I sat down and wrote a new paper as fast as I could.”

In
